Ed Walsh, the great apitball pitcher of
the Chicago White Sox, went wrong in
1909. He spent many years in trying
to recover his lost skill. Several times

of the game for four years. He was he announced a “come-back."" He pitch-
only 29 when he made an €effart to ed part of games now and then and
come back with Ciricinnati. His effort pronounced himself as good as ever.

was a lamentable failure. Some of the
men he had pitched against when at the
height of his fame batted against him
at Cincinnati What they did to him
was pitiful.

Joe Corbett, brother of James J. Cor-
bett, was one of the best curve-ball
pitchers of his era. He had a good ten
years in the major league and quit to
take up business in San Francisco. In
1917 Corbett, only 42, had an idea that
he could come back. He had taken the
very best of care of himself and felt as
young as he did when he made his

If he started a game and showed signs
of weakness he was at once taken out,
and if he finished a game nothing much
could happen to him. So he cajoled him-
sel? into the belief that he was as good
as ever he had been,

Finally, the White Sox released him
and he induced the Boston Nationals
to give him areal triaL Stallings, man-
ager of Boston, knew it would be kind-
ness to let Walsh know really how
thimgs were with him. He put him in
@ game and kept him in there until be
was willing to admit that he was not
as good as he had been.

to get a job pitching baseball
major league club.

Powell pitched his first major league
fame for Cleveland in 189. He
sent to Fort Wayne for further devel-
opment. In 1898 he returned to Cleve-
land and made good with a vengeance.

He won his first ten games in the ma-
jor league. Lou Criger, afterwards fa-
mous as one of the best throwing catch-
ers that ever played baseball, was Pow-
ell’s recelver in those days. Criger has
been out of the game for ten years,
Powell thinks that he has pitching left
in him, though he has not pitched a
major league game in six years. Nor
has he pitched any sort of a game for
two years. Add to that that he has
been in the saloon business for three
years.

Powell may come back—in a way. His
arm is as good, he says, as it ever was
There can be no doubt about that. Pow-
ell always worked easily and hada good
arm. He has shortcomings which age
have not eradicated He never could
field very much. He never was fast on
for a
was

hits a brick wall. No base runner ever
tried to run Spencer off the plate more
than once

The big fellow had three weaknesses—
the wine when it was red, the whisky
when it was yellow and the beer when
it was amber. He managed to joy ride
himself out of the major leagues and
out of the minors, too. After a varied
career of eight years in the woods of
the Northwest, where, he says himself,
he sunk to the lowest depths of bar-
rooms, Spencer made up his mind to
come back. He got a trial with the Los
Angeles team and he came back. Some
twelve years after he got his first trial
with the Browns, 1905, Spencer came
back with the Detroit team and actually
Played better ball—that Is, he hit better
and displayed more tactical acumen—
than he had shown in the halcyon days
of his youth. His arm was not quite
s0 good, but it was good enough for al)
purposes.

Spencer is still with Detroit, a great
eatcher. His is the greatest come back
of all time, yet after the novelty had
worn off the people forgot about him.
He is a good catcher, but to the specta-
tors merely one of the team.

the game. Then, in 1896, after a six-
year lay-off, King got a chance to pitch
for the Washington club. He did splen-
didly, but for the reason that I have
mentioned—the people do not want old-
timers to come back—he was allowed to
return to obscurity in St. Louls.

Had King been a young man thev
would have been after him with brass
bands, But he was near 40, and had
been out of the game for several years
He pitched splendid ball, but nobody
wanted him,
Donlin an Idol.

Mike Donlin laid off in 1908 because
of salary difficulties with New York.
He turned up in 1909 and played fins
ball, Yet McGraw dropped him in 1910
Donlin was an idol in New York. He
had helped win many a championship.
He .was a young man, too, only 23. But
he was old enough to be anything but
a curiosity and they did not want him
when he came back, Donlin, by the way,
would like a job as a pinch hitter in
1918. He, too, wants to come back

Arlio Latham, one of the greatest
coachers that ever lived, left St. Louis,
where he made his fame, in 1890, and
wy

JACK POWELL
WHO AFTER SIX
YEARS REST HOPES
TO COME BACK AS
A PITCHER.
AGE FORTY-FOUR
bett lasted an inning or two.

Many good judges used to say that
Bobby Wallace, the shortstop of the
St. Louls Browns, was the best short-
stop that ever played the position and
one of the two best third basemen ever
seen at the difficult corner. Wallaco
quit playing to accept an umpirical po-
sition in 1915. He quit umpiring and re-
joined the Browns in 1916. In 1917 he
made a special effort to come back fn
the Western League, a fourth rate base-
ball organization.

Wallace had been a staz of the first
magnitude in first-class company, but
the ‘“‘bushers" of the Western ran him
off the lot in 1917. It was “Get out cf
the way, you old stiff,” from boys he
could have blown away In a breath dur-
ing his halcyon days.

One of the greatest efforts to come
back ever made by an athlete was that
made by Janes J. Jeffries when he con-
sented to come out of retirement and,
for the honor of the white race, recover
the heavyweight pugilistic champlon-
ship from the negro, Jack Johnson.
Jeffries trained bard, as he only could
train, for three months. Columns were

That day was done some eight years
Seymour had had fourteen years
of big league success. One would fancy
that would have been enough. Nota
bit of it. Seymour untill] last year regu-
larly reported at the Polo Grounds,

New York, took his practice with <ne
Giants, and watched all their games, He
still believes that he can come back.
He is about 44 years old. Only a few
men of that age have even managed to
stay in the major leagues Anson, Wasg-
ner, Lajole and Young ara probably the
only men who saw their 45th year in a
major league uniform, They were in
harness all the time and were for-
tunate, indeed, to last so long as they
did. The average player begins to rétro-
grade‘at 38 and !s lucky if he sees 38
in the major leagues. Yet men like Sey-
mour, Powell and Donlin want to come
back in the 40s.

Mordecai Brown, the Hon-hearted
pitcher of the great Qubs of 1906-10, lost
his cunning in 1912 He was sent to
CincinnatL In 1915 Mordecal got a
chance to pitch In the Federal League.
The joke batters of that organization
drove him to the woods. Yet Brown
could not belleve that he had gone back
aco.

them comes along once in ten years,
Powell was not one of them. He always
weighed 210 pounds. He should have
weighed 180.
Can They Come Back.

Powell's persistence has brought up
the old question of “Can they come back
after having been out of the game for
years?" ,

_ Then, having disposec of that ques-
tion, add this one, ‘Do the people want
them when they do come back?"

To,the first of these questions I would
answer, “Perhaps.” To the second,
“They do not.”

I have seen many men, horses, dogs,
ete., come back. Yet I never have seen
any great demand among the people
that they should come back, or, having
come, stay.

bu: his numerous escapades, such as
fighting with members of his own team,
spectators, policemen and hotel watch-
_ men, seem to have endeared him to the

people. George Slisler, the best behaved
of boys, never will be so popular as
Cobb, Mathewson, the pink of deport-
ment, never was wildly idolized as the
utterly irresponsible boy, Waddell, was
idolized. Sullivan, the wild fighter; Tod
Sloan, the fast-living jockey, all were
idols in their days.

There is something about the wild boy
that people love, No other ballplayers
have been idolized as Kelly and Wad-
dell, sports, were idolized. Sullivan was
the idol among the prize fightors. Tod
Sloan’s champagne suppers and great
cigars made him tho idol of those who
admired horsemanship. Maybe it is this
disposition to admire the wild and trre-

But the people who adored him when
he was with St. Louis in the 80s would
none of him with New York twenty-two
years later. His journeys to the coach-
ing lines were pathetic. So after a trial
McGraw let Latham go,

George McQuillan was rated the great-
est pitcher in baseball in 1907, He went
badly one year and was sent to the
minors, McQuillan, a sturdy chap,
braced up and did such good work in
the minors that he was taken back to
the big leagues via Pittsburgh. Yet Mc-
Quillan really never came back. Ore of
the very best of pitchers, a poem in ac-
tion, a beautiful flelder, McQuillan
never regained a tithe of the popularity
that was his in the days of his wild
youth. The people lost confidence in his
abllity to win. When he went into the
box he did not have the crowd with him.
sop,

Young retired from the Cleveland
club in 1912 and dropped out of the
game. In 1913 he was induced to ac-
copt the management of the Cleveland
Federal League team. He tried to pitch
in that tenth class organization. The
miserable batters of the Federal League
drove him off the slab, where he had
been a king for twenty-two years, a
king among kings.

Smmet Heldrick, who was with the
St. Louis Nationals and Browns in the
early 1900s, was one of the very great-
est outfielders of the game, a man who
in his time was regarded as are Cobb
and Speaker regarded today. He was
only twenty-six years old when he re-
tired. He Was out of the game for five
yearre, when his former manager, James
A. McAleer, belng in great need of a

in Pennsylvania. He did rot have to
take off a pound of welght when he re-
juined his club after a five-year ab-
sence, But he was as a little child
when he tried to play major league ball
among his old team mates.
Rusie Hard on Batters.

Amos Rusie, the great players of the
S0s and 1900s will tell you, was the
hardest pitcher to hit they ever batted
against Rusie made his first appear-
ance in the major leagues with Indlan-
apolis In 1889, He was only 19 years
old. For the following six years he was
the terror of all batters that faced him.
He had tremendous speed and a curve
bal! the Ike of which never had heen
seen, nor has its like been seen since,

That curve broke right at the batter’s
ear and shot down over the plate. It

Corbett put up a wonderfully skillful
fight. Jeffries could not hit him and at
the end of twenty-three rounds it
seemed that Corbett would be champion
on points, for the fight was limited to
twenty-five rounds In the twenty-
fourth round Jeffries managed to catch
Corbett with a right-hand swing. Jim
did not come back.

Corbett tried it again two years later.
He figured that he was not as strong
as he might have been when he met
Jeffries before and this tlme he trained
especially for strength He said that be
never felt so strong in his life as when
“he went into the ring to fight. He

lasted something like nine rounds. He
told mo afterwards that he was really
licked by a blow in the stomach in the
second round.

and McQuillan, veterans who did suc-
ceed in making successful come-backs,
the fact
to see baseball games do not want the
Is that the people who pay

veterans to come back. That is to say,
they are not interested in them. They
are not against them. Nelther are they
for them. This very feeling works to-
ward failure for the old fellows.

The truth is that baseball is a young
man’s game. It is played best when
played by boys. The promising young
player Is of more value to the baseball
club than ten possible “come-backs”’
who are veterans. Even the veteran
in the flower of his career is not so
interesting as the boy. .

Youth, speed, soundness of limb, am-
bition, ingeniousness, eagerness, the
possibilities of success are the things
that make a boy Interesting to the peo-
